newsitem.title: ITALY: SOCCER-JUVENTUS NOT WORRIED BY LOSS OF FORM.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-JUVENTUS NOT WORRIED BY LOSS OF FORM.

text.p: Italian league leaders Juventus travel to Paris for Wednesday's European Supercup clash with French side Paris St. Germain, apparently unconcerned by a recent loss of form.

While the French club were preparing in the sunshine of Reunion in the Indian Ocean, Juventus were going through a mini-slump in wintry Italy, picking up just two points in their last three league games to now lead joint second-placed teams Sampdoria and Internazionale by just two points.

Draws with Piacenza and Atalanta and a defeat last week by Parma contrast with the bright form shown by Juventus during an unbeaten autumn run in the Champions League, a period when Juventus also won the World Club cup in Tokyo.

Club coach Marcello Lippi argues that a temporary loss of form during a long season is normal, saying after Sunday's 0-0 home draw with Atalanta : "If anyone thinks that a team can remain 100 per cent for 11 months, then he doesn't know much about Italian soccer.
"There's always going to be a period, in this case perhaps co-incidental with our Christmas training load, when the side is not its usual brilliant self".
Experienced Juventus defender Ciro Ferrara agrees with his coach, playing down the team's recent dip.
"Is it the Tokyo effect ? I don't know...the important thing now is to limit the damages but we don't need to get ourselves worked up about it since, after all, we're still out in front".
For the first leg of the Supercup, Juventus will be without Croat striker Alen Boksic, who picked up an ankle injury against Atalanta.
Captain Antonio Conte is still out with a long-term injury while Portugese defender Manuel Dimas is cup-tied.
Michele Padovano will probably join Alessandro Del Piero in attack with Nicola Amoruso on stand-by.
One player who may not feature in the Paris game is striker Christian Vieri, who came on as a substitute for Boksic against Atalanta but was then himself substituted by Amoruso after only 20 minutes.
Although media speculation suggests Vieri had an angry dressing room disagreement with Lippi at halftime, the coach himself claimed that he had substituted Vieri for "technical reasons", adding :
"I sent on Amoruso because I needed a player who would put himself about and tempt the Atalanta defenders out of their own penalty area".

Wednesday's game is one of two potentially difficult games this week for Juventus who on Sunday travel south to face Lazio in Rome for a match which marks the halfway point in the 34 game Serie A season.
Lippi argues that his side's recent mini-setbacks just prove that the Italian title race is wide open.
"It wasn't just our closest rivals, Inter and Sampdoria, who won today but also Milan and Parma.
"We've always said that the championship battle was far from finished and none of the contenders are yet out of the contest," he said.
